title: Yes-No Game (1)
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. You are not allowed to use the words 'yes' or 'no' and you're not allowed to give a clear positive or negative answer. You need to speak like (some) politicians do.
cards: Are you enjoying this class?
Are you going to have dinner tonight?
Did you, at any point in your life, like Justin Bieber?
Do you smoke?
Do you think UFOs exist?
Do you like today's weather?
Could you ride a bike when you were five?
Would you like to win the lottery?
Is London the capital city of the UK?
Have you ever seen a Spiderman movie?
Have you ever fallen in love at first sight?
Is your hair black?
Do you think Real Madrid is the best football team in the world?
Are you going out tonight?
Can you play the musical instrument called the triangle?
Are you French?
Are kangaroos humans?
Have you ever seen an elephant in a cherry tree?
Are you vegetarian?
Did you clean your shoes yesterday?

title: Exam Questions – B1 (1)
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: What do you do/study?
How do you get to work or school every day?
What did you do yesterday evening?
What did you do last weekend?
Do you think that English will be useful for you in the future? Why?
Tell us about the people you live with.
What do you do when you want to relax?
Do you prefer to relax with friends or alone? Why?
Is it important to do exercise in your free time? Why? / Why not?
Is it useful to learn new skills in your free time? Why? / Why not?
Do you think people spend too much time working or studying these days? Why? / Why not?

title: Exam Questions – B2 (1)
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: Where are you from? What do you like about living there?
How do you like to spend your evenings? What do you do? Why?
Do you prefer to spend time on your own or with other people? Why?
Tell us about a film you really like?
Do you like cooking? What sort of things do you cook?
Do you normally celebrate special occasions with friends or family? Why?
Tell us about a festival or celebration in your country.
What did you do on your last birthday?
Are you going to do anything special this weekend? Where are you going to go? What are you going to do?
How much TV do you watch in a week? Would you prefer to watch more TV than that or less? Why?
Tell us about a TV programme you've seen recently.
Do you use the internet much? Why? / Why not?
Do you ever listen to the radio? What programmes do you like? Why?

title: Exam Questions – C1 (1)
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: Where are you from? What do you do there?
How long have you been studying English?
What do you enjoy most about learning English?
What free time activity do you most enjoy? Why?
What sort of work would you like to do in the future? Why?
Do you think you spend too much time working or studying? Why? / Why not?
Do you like using the internet to keep in touch with people?
Have you celebrated anything recently? How?
If you could travel to one country in the world, where would you go? Why?
How important is it to you to spend time with your family? Why? / Why not?
Who do you think has had the greatest influence on your life? / Why?

title: What would you do if ...?
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: (get) an anonymous love letter
your neighbour (play) loud music all night, every night
someone you didn't like (invite) you to a really good concert
your mom (start) showing the photo album of you as a baby to your boyfriend/girlfriend
(find) $30,000 in the street
(meet) your English teacher at a disco
(see) a cockroach in the kitchen
someone (offer) you $10,000 every time they punched you in the face
(can) snap your fingers and make any one species go extinct
(can) body swap with any person for 24 hours
(be) suddenly given world-class hacking knowledge and ability?
(can) go back and undo one thing you did in the past
never (need) to sleep again
a kid (start) kicking you in the park and his mother (not stop) him
(have) the opportunity to time travel once
(have to) choose between winning the lottery or living twice as long
(go) to the hairdesser's and (get) a really bad haircut

title: Talking about food
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: Do you like foreign food, eg. Indian, Chinese, Italian and English food? Which do you like best?
Is your diet healthy or unhealthy? Why?
What kind of healthy food do you hate?
What kind of unhealthy food do you like?
Is there anything you try not to eat or drink too often?
Do you eat fat-free or low-fat food?
What do you usually eat when you eat out?
How often do you eat junk food?
Which do you prefer, fast food or home-cooked food?
What food do you avoid eating to stay healthy?
How important is food in your life?
Are you a vegetarian or vegan? If not, do you think you could ever be one?
Do you usually have breakfast? What do you normally have?

title: Shopping habits
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: Which one do you enjoy more, shopping for food or shopping for clothes? Why?
Where do you normally buy your clothes? Do you have a favourite place?
How often do you buy new clothes?
What is the most important for you when you're shopping: quality, the price or a brand?
Do you know someone who has too many clothes?
What is your favourite item of clothing right now?
Have you ever bought anything that you've hardly ever worn?
Do you prefer to buy clothes on your own, with a family member or with a friend?
Do you enjoy shopping at the sales?
Do you like shopping in large supermarkets?
Are you good at finding good deals?

title: Talking about friendship (1)
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: What makes a good friend?
Do you think you will keep in touch with your friends all your life?
How many close friends do you have? How many of them can humans have?
Can you describe one of your closest friends and the qualities you like about him/her?
Do you have any childhood friends you're still friends with?
Do you have any long-distance friends? How do you keep in touch? How often do you see each other?
Do you make friends easily?
How would you compare your present friendships with your childhood ones?
What do we need to do to maintain a good friendship?
How do you make new friends?

title: Talking about friendship (2)
instructions: Work in pairs using one phone between you. Take turns to ask and answer the questions. Talk about each question for a minute. When it's your turn to answer a question, try to only listen to your parner without looking at the phone. When you're asking your partner, don't accept a short answer.
cards: What do you think of friendships that are made across generations? What are the advantages and disadvantages?
What do you normally do with your friends?
What is the longest friendship that you have had?
What makes friends different from family?
Do you think it is possible to be friends with someone of the opposite sex?
Can you give examples of how a friend has influenced your life?
Why do we need friends? What are friends for?
What do you do when you have a disagreement with your friend?
What qualities help you to have good relationships with others?
To what extent can you be friends with your parents or children?
